results.title: Ladri di biciclette = Bicycle thieves
results.creator_credit: Vittorio De Sica, Umberto Scarpelli, De Sica Productions and Ente Nazionale Industrie Cinematografiche (ENIC)
results.brief_description:
A man and his son search for his stolen bicycle which he needs to hold his job as a bill poster; without the bicyle he is condemned to unemployment. This remains an important film although the reasons for its importance have changed over time. What is now most apparent is a particular stylisation which passed for realism. The use of non-professional actors, real locations and the absence of a complex story-line and characterisation, disguise the carefully calculated and detailed mise-en-scene, the stylised representation of an authentic environment. The son has been set up to create a sentimental commentary on the central dilemma. This engenders an empathy with the characters qualitatively different from the more usual identification. Alternate version also available on 16mm. Also available on VHS and laserdisc.

Credits: Production manager, Umberto Scarpelli ; director, Vittorio de Sica ; writers, Vittorio de Sica, Suso d’Amico, Cesare Zavattini ; photography, Carlo Montuori ; production designer, Antonio Traverso ; music, Allesandro Cigognini ; editor, Erald
Cast: Lamberto Maggiorani, Enzo Staiola, Lianella Carell, Gino Saltamerenda.

results.title: Det Sjunde inseglet = The Seventh seal
results.brief_description:
The title refers to God’s book of secrets in which the greatest gift, the secret of life, will be revealed only after the breaking of the seventh seal. In this film which Bergman calls an oratorio, and The Virgin Spring (1959) he tried to purge the uglier aspects of religious practice as well as confront the silence of God in the face of what he saw an ‘an active evil’. The Seventh Seal is a morality play set in doom-laden 14th century Sweden. Although in some ways the film’s psychological and erotic concerns are modern and the world weary knight who challenges Death to a game of chess is a distinctly modern hero, Bergman chose the medieval period for the way in which thought was then embodied iconographically, providing the basis for the film’s striking imagery. Also available on VHS and LD.

Credits: Director, Ingmar Bergman ; photographer, Gunnar Fischer ; production designer, P.A. Lundgren ; music, Erik Nordgren.
Cast: Gunnar Bjornstrand, Benyt Ekerot, Nils Poppe, Max Von Sydow, Bibi Anderson.

results.title: The General
results.creator_credit: Buster Keaton, Clyde Bruckman, Joseph Schenck and Buster Keaton Productions
results.brief_description:
Keaton, an engine driver, recaptures his train and rescues his girl after it has been stolen and she has been kidnapped by Union soldiers from behind Confederate lines. Based on an actual incident in the Civil War this is widely regarded as Keaton’s finest film. Oblivious to the dictates of normal comprehension, Keaton as Johnny its own.

Credits: Producer, Joseph M. Schenck ; directors, Buster Keaton, Clyde Bruckmann ; writers, Al Boasberg, Charles Smith ; photography, J. Devereaux Jennings, Bert Haines ; piano accompaniment, William Perry.
Cast: Buster Keaton, Marion Mack, Glen Cavander.

results.title: Steamboat Bill Jr. (Musical Soundtrack)
results.creator_credit: Charles Reisner and Buster Keaton Productions
results.brief_description:
Set in the Deep South with Keaton as the wimpish son of a steamboat captain who ultimately proves himself in helping his father fight off a wealthy rival. Particularly memorable is the hat-buying sequence and the remarkably staged cyclone sequence in which the town is destroyed around a stoic Buster. Version without musical soundtrack also available on 16mm.

Credits: Director, Chas F. Reisner ; photographers, Dev Jennings, Bert Haines ; writers, Carl Harbaugh, Buster Keaton ; piano accompaniment, William Perry.
Cast: Buster Keaton, Tom McGuire, Ernest Torrence, Tom Lewis, Marion Byron.

results.title: La Regle du jeu = Rules of the game
results.creator_credit: Jean Renoir, Claude Renoir and Nouvelle Edition Francaise
results.brief_description:
Renoir’s portrayal of a weekend house party in the country is, in effect, the portrayal of a society in crisis, a social world in which there are rules but no values. On the surface the film is a comedy of manners based on the tradition of 18th century French theatre. Its richness lies in the contrast between ambiguity and clarity, the elaborate parallelisms between groups and specific characters and a pathbreaking melange of stylistic techniques. Renoir ironically exposes the moral bankruptcy of this world while remaining consistent with the model of classical theatre in his deployment of closure. The film’s influence lies in Renoir’s modernism. In portraying life-as-flux he juxtaposes what in his hands are formal devices for openness (mobile camera, depth of field, use of off-screen space) with the closure of classical narrative implied by, for example, shot-counter-shot editing. Also available on VHS and LD.

Credits: Director, Jean Renoir ; producer, Claude Renoir ; photography, Jean Bachelet ; writers, Jean Renoir, Carl Koch ; music, Joseph Kosma, Roger Desormieres.
Cast: Marcel Dalio, Roland Toutain, Nora Gregor, Jean Renoir.

results.title: Several days in the life of I.I. Oblomov
results.brief_description:
Oblomov is based on a gently satirical novel by Ivan Goncharov set in the mid-nineteenth century about an absentee landlord who stays in bed because he cannot find a convincing reason for getting up. He has tried getting up in the past but sees no reason to go on with it. Moreover, as a man of means he is in the position of being able to choose not to go on with it. ‘(An) engagingly adapted parable of a privileged recluse being reluctantly dragged towards light, life and love…As the tardily socialised eternally indecisive Oblomov, Tabakov invests sloth with a winning seductiveness’ (Paul Taylor in Time Out). Another print also available on 16mm.

Credits: Director, Nikita Mikhalkov ; script, A. Adabashian, N. Mikhalkov ; photography, Pavel Lebeshev ; music, E. Artemiev.
Cast: Oleg Tabakov, Yuri Bogatyryov, Andrei Popov, Yelena Solovei.

results.title: Carry on up the Khyber (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Gerald Thomas, Peter Rogers, Peter Rogers Productions and Rank Film Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Carry on”.
It is 1895 and the British occupation of India is threatened by revolutionary uprisings. In order for the revolutionaries to attack the British troops they need to cross the notorious Khyber Pass. The history and politics of the British Raj, however, is simply a convenient background for the Carry On team to conduct their regular mix of hilarious slap-stick and tongue-in-cheek camp. Cast includes Sidney James, Kenneth Williams, Joan Sims and a large supporting cast of British comedians.

results.title: Kakushi Toride No San Akunin = The Hidden Fortress (Cinemascope Print)
results.creator_credit: Akira Kurosawa, Masumi Fujimoto and Toho Kabushiki Kaisha
results.brief_description:
A jidai geki (period film) set during the civil war of the sixteenth century. A young princess is trying to travel across war-torn territory with her clan’s treasure accompanied by a loyal samurai (Mifune) and two oafish peasants. This film is notable for the way Kurosawa brings some complexity to what could have been a conventional chambara (sword-play film). He overlays satire, Shakesperian contrasts between clown and hero and references to the American western on more traditional elements such as Noh music and story-structure close to fairy tale. Kurosawa also makes what Noel Burch regards as distinctively Japanese use of the wide screen (Cinemascope) proportions in decentred compositions which, like some traditional Japanese painting, frequently emphasises the shape and boundaries of the frame. Also available on VHS and 16mm.

Credits: Producer, Masumi Fujimoto ; director, Akira Kurosawa ; writers, Shinobu Hashimoto, Hideo Oguni, Ryuzo Kikushima, Kurosawa ; photography, Ichio Yamasaki ; music, Masaru Sato.
Cast: Toshiro Mifune, Misa Uehara, Minoru Chiaki, Kamatari Fujiwara, Susumu Fujita.

results.title: Les Noces rouges = Blood wedding
results.creator_credit: Claude Chabrol, Andre Genoves, Canaria Films and Les Films de la Boetie
results.brief_description:
This French thriller was banned at the time of its release ostensibly because it resembled a true murder case but pundits claimed it message operated too closely as a parable for the French elections being held at the time. Lucienne Delamare, the mayor of a small town in the Loire Valley discovers that his wife is having an affair with his deputy, and decides to blackmail the latter into going along with a crooked property deal. The scheme is to redevelop a high-rise dwelling and factory for workers, but Lucienne will be the principal beneficiary. ‘Les Noces Rouge’ is another variation on Chabrol’s pet theme of infidelity leading to murder and is as elegant and cool as one expects from a director secure in his subject. A darkly comic tale of revenge, greed and petty corruption.

Credits: Producer, Andre Genoves ; director, writer, Claude Chabrol ; photography, Jean Rabier ; music, Pierre Jansen ; editing, Jacques Gaillard, Monique Gaillard.
Cast: Michel Piccoli, Stephan Audran, Clotilde Joano, Eliana De Santis, Ermanno Casanova.

results.title: Shichinin no Samurai = Seven Samurai
results.creator_credit: Akira Kurosawa, Shojiro Motoki and Toho Kabushiki Kaisha
results.brief_description:
Kurosawa’s peerless action drama overthrew fixed notions of genre in placing the chambara (sword-play) film within a meaningful past and tempering social drama (jidai-geki) with comedy. It translated into the ethos of the Western as The Magnificient Seven. The position of the ronin, defenders of civilised society yet placed outside it, is not dissimilar to that of the Westerner - a humanist existentialism crossing cultural boundaries. However, in contrast to the Western where history is most often a pretext, Kurosawa locates his characters firmly in a specific historical context - the chaotic period of civil wars in the 16th century before the relative peace of the Tokugawa period (1600-1868). Also available on 16mm, LD and VHS.

Credits: Director, Akira Kurosawa ; producer, Sojiro Motoki ; script, Akira Kurosawa, Shinobu Hashimoto, Hideo Oguni ; photography, Asaichi Nakai ; [music, Fumio Hayasaka].
Cast: Toshiro Mifune, Takashi Shimura, Keiko Tsushima, Kamatari Fujiwara.

description_for_label:
Kurosawa’s peerless action drama overthrew fixed notions of genre in placing the chambara (sword-play) film within a meaningful past and tempering social drama (jidai-geki) with comedy. It translated into the ethos of the Western as The Magnificient Seven. The position of the ronin, defenders of civilised society yet placed outside it, is not dissimilar to that of the Westerner - a humanist existentialism crossing cultural boundaries. However, in contrast to the Western where history is most often a pretext, Kurosawa locates his characters firmly in a specific historical context - the chaotic period of civil wars in the 16th century before the relative peace of the Tokugawa period (1600-1868). Also available on 16mm, LD and VHS.

Credits: Director, Akira Kurosawa ; producer, Sojiro Motoki ; script, Akira Kurosawa, Shinobu Hashimoto, Hideo Oguni ; photography, Asaichi Nakai ; [music, Fumio Hayasaka].
Cast: Toshiro Mifune, Takashi Shimura, Keiko Tsushima, Kamatari Fujiwara.
